author: By Noah Weiland
title: Impeachment Briefing: Senate Votes to Block Witnesses
description: Party leaders agreed on a schedule that would end the trial on Wednesday.
content: Read our full story on the day, some key takeaways, and an analysis of how Mr. Trump’s control of Senate Republicans is nearly complete.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: Elizabeth Warren misses her rally but makes it to the afterparty.
description: Ms. Warren’s campaign schedule had been upended by the impeachment proceedings, but she greeted fans later in the evening at a brewery in Des Moines.
content: DES MOINES — Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts rallied supporters at a local Des Moines brewery late Friday night, in a surprise visit only possible after she arrived late from Washington and the Senate impeachment trial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember
title: It’s not just Iowans scoping out candidates.
description: In the crowd at Bernie Sanders’s first event of his final swing through Iowa, there were some unlikely attendees: More than two dozen Australians.
content: INDIANOLA — In the crowd at Bernie Sanders’s first event of his final swing through Iowa at a college here in Indianola, there were some unlikely attendees: More than two dozen Australians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Biden’s surrogates take the stump.
description: Joe Biden has been leaning heavily on a stable of surrogates to boost his message in the final weeks before the Iowa caucuses.
content: NORTH LIBERTY — Mr. Biden has been leaning heavily on a stable of surrogates to boost his message in the final weeks before the Iowa caucuses. In attendance at his first event of the day here: Representative Abby Finkenauer, Democrat of Iowa, who helped kick off the event, and former Secretary of State John Kerry, the 2004 Democratic nominee who won the Iowa caucuses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: The candidates in their own words.
description: These speeches, which the candidates deliver multiple times a day, provide a window into how they hope to appeal to Iowans in the final days before the caucuses.
content: DES MOINES — The candidates give them every day, often multiple times a day, and in some cases so consistently that the reporters who follow them from event to event can practically recite them from memory. Yes, we’re talking about stump speeches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: On Roofs or in Basements, a New Way to Ice Skate
description: With stackable plastic panels, a company called Glice wants to be rink-builder to a warming world.
content: It was a charming winter tableau, suitable for a postcard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Peyser and Pete Gamlen
title: The Super Bowl Ads You Won’t See This Year
description: Many viewers don’t care about the game but watch for the commercials. Not these.
content: Attention, if you or a loved one received a diagnosis of chronic traumatic encephalopathy, or C.T.E., you may be entitled to financial compensation. C.T.E. is caused by repeated head injuries and linked to playing professional football. Please, don’t wait. Call 1-555-STOP-NFL for a free legal consultation and a claims packet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Delaware turns out for Biden.
description: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. began his second event of the day by introducing the Delaware crew that had turned out to support him.
content: CEDAR RAPIDS — Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. began his second event of the day by introducing the Delaware crew that had turned out to support him here in the Iowa homestretch, including Senators Tom Carper and Chris Coons and Representative Lisa Blunt Rochester.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: Elizabeth Warren focuses on unity.
description: Ms. Warren kicked off her final blitz of campaign events Saturday afternoon, pitching herself as a candidate who can unite the Democratic Party’s moderate and progressive factions.
content: CEDAR RAPIDS — Senator Elizabeth Warren kicked off her final blitz of campaign events Saturday afternoon, pitching herself as a candidate who can unite the Democratic Party’s moderate and progressive factions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes
title: Diplomat at Center of Trump Impeachment Retires From State Department
description: On a July 25 telephone call with the president of Ukraine, President Trump described Ambassador Yovanovitch as “bad news” and said, ominously, “She’s going to go through some things.”
content: WASHINGTON — The American ambassador whose abrupt recall from Ukraine helped lead to President Trump’s impeachment has retired from the State Department, a person familiar with her plans confirmed on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: Elizabeth Warren misses her rally but makes it to the afterparty.
description: Ms. Warren’s campaign schedule had been upended by the impeachment proceedings, but she greeted fans later in the evening at a brewery in Des Moines.
content: DES MOINES — Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts rallied supporters at a local Des Moines brewery late Friday night, in a surprise visit only possible after she arrived late from Washington and the Senate impeachment trial.
source.name: The New York Times

title: It’s not just Iowans scoping out candidates.
description: In the crowd at Bernie Sanders’s first event of his final swing through Iowa, there were some unlikely attendees: More than two dozen Australians.
content: INDIANOLA — In the crowd at Bernie Sanders’s first event of his final swing through Iowa at a college here in Indianola, there were some unlikely attendees: More than two dozen Australians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Biden’s surrogates take the stump.
description: Joe Biden has been leaning heavily on a stable of surrogates to boost his message in the final weeks before the Iowa caucuses.
content: NORTH LIBERTY — Mr. Biden has been leaning heavily on a stable of surrogates to boost his message in the final weeks before the Iowa caucuses. In attendance at his first event of the day here: Representative Abby Finkenauer, Democrat of Iowa, who helped kick off the event, and former Secretary of State John Kerry, the 2004 Democratic nominee who won the Iowa caucuses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: The candidates in their own words.
description: These speeches, which the candidates deliver multiple times a day, provide a window into how they hope to appeal to Iowans in the final days before the caucuses.
content: DES MOINES — The candidates give them every day, often multiple times a day, and in some cases so consistently that the reporters who follow them from event to event can practically recite them from memory. Yes, we’re talking about stump speeches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Requiem for a Dream
description: Britain exits Europe. It will be poorer, above all in its shriveled heart.
content: I have covered many stories that marked me over the past 40 years, in war zones and outside them, but none that has affected me as personally as Britain’s exit from the European Union. Brexit Day, now upon us, feels like the end of hope, a moral collapse, a self-amputation that will make the country where I grew up poorer in every sense.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tara Houska
title: My Culture Is Not Super Bowl Entertainment
description: The matchup between the Kansas City Chiefs and the San Francisco 49ers brings out the worst Native Americans stereotypes.
content: A few weeks ago, as I walked through security at the Minneapolis-St. Paul airport, a T.S.A. agent grabbed onto my braids and snapped them like reins. “Giddy up!” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Bernie’s Angry Bros
description: The Sanders online army resembles President Trump’s most ardent supporters in more ways than either side might care to admit.
content: Barbara Boxer minces no words when it comes to describing the people usually known as the Bernie Bros — a subset of Bernie Sanders supporters who hope to take over the Democratic Party and remake it in their image.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: Somewhere Between a Shared Cab and a Private Jet, It’s the Commuter Helicopter
description: In traffic-clogged cities around the world, the skies are abuzz with helicopters.
content: Private jets are the ultimate symbol of our new Gilded Age: Ever more popular with the very wealthy, they have induced a sort of hand-wringing among more progressive-minded billionaires.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: On Roofs or in Basements, a New Way to Ice Skate
description: With stackable plastic panels, a company called Glice wants to be rink-builder to a warming world.
content: It was a charming winter tableau, suitable for a postcard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eve Peyser and Pete Gamlen
title: The Super Bowl Ads You Won’t See This Year
description: Many viewers don’t care about the game but watch for the commercials. Not these.
content: Attention, if you or a loved one received a diagnosis of chronic traumatic encephalopathy, or C.T.E., you may be entitled to financial compensation. C.T.E. is caused by repeated head injuries and linked to playing professional football. Please, don’t wait. Call 1-555-STOP-NFL for a free legal consultation and a claims packet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Delaware turns out for Biden.
description: Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. began his second event of the day by introducing the Delaware crew that had turned out to support him.
content: CEDAR RAPIDS — Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. began his second event of the day by introducing the Delaware crew that had turned out to support him here in the Iowa homestretch, including Senators Tom Carper and Chris Coons and Representative Lisa Blunt Rochester.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon
title: Elizabeth Warren focuses on unity.
description: Ms. Warren kicked off her final blitz of campaign events Saturday afternoon, pitching herself as a candidate who can unite the Democratic Party’s moderate and progressive factions.
content: CEDAR RAPIDS — Senator Elizabeth Warren kicked off her final blitz of campaign events Saturday afternoon, pitching herself as a candidate who can unite the Democratic Party’s moderate and progressive factions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Welcome to the final stretch.
description: The Iowa caucuses are two days away, and with the impeachment trial adjourned for the weekend, the top candidates are all on the ground.
content: DES MOINES — The Iowa caucuses are only two days away, and with the Senate impeachment trial adjourned for the weekend, the top candidates are all on the ground, sprinting to the finish line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember
title: Bernie Sanders takes a poll.
description: After surveying the room, he declared himself the winner “based on a deep analysis and investigation of the American electorate.”
content: GRINNELL — During a quick stop with supporters at a coffee shop, Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont again emphasized his ability to beat President Trump in November — but he did so lightheartedly.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tulsi Gabbard’s presence in Iowa.
description: The congresswoman from Hawaii has billboards in Iowa while she campaigns in New Hampshire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles Dunst
title: ‘BoJack Horseman’ Ended With a Necessary Reckoning
description: The Netflix show forced its problematic lead — and viewers — to confront the consequences of his actions.
content: This essay contains spoilers for the final season of “BoJack Horseman.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: A Dishonorable Senate
description: Republican legislators abdicated their duty by refusing to seek the truth.
content: Alas, no one ever lost money betting on the cynicism of today’s congressional Republicans. On Friday evening, Republican senators voted in near lock step to block testimony from any new witnesses or the production of any new documents, a vote that was tantamount to an acquittal of the impeachment charges against President Trump. The move can only embolden the president to cheat in the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz and Matt Stevens
title: A 2020 Democratic Primary Endorsement Digest
description: Joe Biden has a hold on the Democratic establishment. Much of the far left supports Bernie Sanders. Mayors are backing Pete Buttigieg and Mike Bloomberg. And then there are the celebrities.
content: John Kerry is for Joe Biden. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez is stumping for Bernie Sanders. And Julián Castro is for Elizabeth Warren. But whom does George Takei support? (Hint: A certain former mayor from Indiana …)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman, John Schwartz and Mark Walker
title: NOAA Leaders Privately Disowned Agency’s Rebuke of Scientists Who Contradicted Trump
description: Newly released emails show officials at NOAA told the agency’s scientists it did “not approve or support” a controversial agency statement issued after the president falsely said that Alabama was at risk from Hurricane Dorian.
content: WASHINGTON — Senior officials with the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration privately disavowed an unsigned statement issued by the agency last year that rebuked its own weather forecasters for contradicting President Trump’s false warnings that Hurricane Dorian would most likely hit Alabama, new documents show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Fact-Checking Bernie Sanders Before the Iowa Caucuses
description: The Vermont senator has made exaggerated claims or statements that lacked context about “Medicare for all,” his antiwar record and his history of bipartisanship.
content: Before the first votes are cast in the Democratic presidential contest, The New York Times reviewed statements Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont has made promoting his signature “Medicare for all” proposal, highlighting his long-held opposition to military intervention and arguing that he can work across the aisle. Here’s a fact-check.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor and Matt Stevens
title: How Will the Winner of the Iowa Caucuses Be Chosen? Here’s What You Should Know
description: As if the caucusing wasn’t confusing enough, officials will release raw vote totals that could allow candidates to spin the results.
content: DES MOINES — Once upon a time, the winner of the Iowa caucuses was obvious to everyone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin and Alexander Burns
title: Democratic Candidates Focus on All-Consuming Hunger to Unseat Trump
description: With the Iowa caucuses set to kick off the primary season on Monday night, a Democratic race that began as a contest of ideas and ideologies has given way to a fixation on electability.
content: SIOUX CITY, Iowa — After a long campaign of ideological clashes, policy debates and talk of a grand reckoning on the direction of the Democratic Party, the presidential primaries starting on Monday will be shaped by a less lofty but increasingly urgent matter: determining the best candidate to defeat an incumbent who has already proved to be a political survivor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck and Steve Eder
title: Why Jill Biden Is Taking Time Off to Help Her Husband Get a Job
description: She is a forceful surrogate for Joe Biden’s campaign, in part because voters like that she has retained her own professional identity: “I admire how she’s always worked.”
content: CENTERVILLE, Iowa — Jill Biden was torn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: With Brexit Official, Britons Start a ‘Brexodus’ From Brussels
description: For many, it was an awkward and wrenching week of farewells. But most are racing to claim different passports, so they might keep lucrative jobs.
content: BRUSSELS — His 13th-floor office with its panoramic views was testament to the high status Claude Moraes had attained as a senior member of the European Parliament. But on a recent morning, it was empty, save his suitcase, a laptop and a phone on his bare desk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg, Katherine Rosman, Sapna Maheshwari and James B. Stewart
title: ‘Angels’ in Hell: The Culture of Misogyny Inside Victoria’s Secret
description: A Times investigation found widespread bullying and harassment of employees and models. The company expresses “regret.”
content: Victoria’s Secret defined femininity for millions of women. Its catalog and fashion shows were popular touchstones. For models, landing a spot as an “Angel” all but guaranteed international stardom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Rothenberg
title: Australian Open: Sofia Kenin Defeats Garbiñe Muguruza for Her First Major Title
description: Kenin, an American in her first Grand Slam final, became the tournament’s youngest singles champion since Maria Sharapova in 2008.
content: MELBOURNE, Australia — Sofia Kenin became the youngest Australian Open champion in 12 years on Saturday night, beating Garbiñe Muguruza 4-6, 6-2, 6-2 to claim her first Grand Slam title.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Yaffe-Bellany
title: Coronavirus Thwarts Business Travelers Who ‘Need to Be in the Room’
description: The growing uncertainty over the safety of visiting or leaving China is bedeviling companies around the world.
content: Alex Richter had a choice: Stay or go.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Watch Live: Senators Debate Impeachment Trial Amendments
description: Senators will vote on procedural motions in President Trump’s impeachment trial.
content: Senators will vote on procedural motions in President Trump’s impeachment trial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Senate adjourns until Monday morning.
description: The move sets a timetable for next week, including a vote on whether to remove President Trump from office.
content: The Senate has adjourned and will reopen as a court of impeachment at 11 a.m. Eastern on Monday, when lawmakers will hear up to four hours closing arguments, divided equally between the impeachment managers and the White House defense team.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Feb. 1, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Feb. 1, 2020.
content: An article on Thursday about Kryptos, a courtyard sculpture  at C.I.A.  headquarters, misstated the decryption at the end of Passage Two. The decryption of those letters is “XLAYERTWO,” not “LEVELTWO.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: At Chelsea, Lampard’s Experiment May Soon Become a Test
description: Chelsea bet on a beloved former player and its young talent this season, and it sits safely in fourth place. But patience will inevitably depend on results.
content: LEICESTER, England — More than a decade ago, one of the world’s foremost cardiovascular health experts tracked the heart rate and blood pressure of two Premier League managers during a game.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Buttigieg strategist says strong Iowa finish would give others ‘permission’ to back him.
description: The inference especially is that black voters, who currently demonstrate little support for the former mayor in polling, would follow the lead of Iowa caucusgoers and rally around him.
content: DES MOINES — Top strategists for Pete Buttigieg said they needed a top finish in Iowa on Monday and in New Hampshire the following week, but that first place was not a make-or-break deal for the campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Senate adjourns until Monday morning.
description: The move sets a timetable for next week, including a vote on whether to remove President Trump from office.
content: The Senate has adjourned and will reopen as a court of impeachment at 11 a.m. Eastern on Monday, when lawmakers will hear up to four hours closing arguments, divided equally between the impeachment managers and the White House defense team.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Watch Live: Senators Debate Impeachment Trial Amendments
description: Senators will vote on procedural motions in President Trump’s impeachment trial.
content: Senators will vote on procedural motions in President Trump’s impeachment trial.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Feb. 1, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Feb. 1, 2020.
content: An article on Thursday about Kryptos, a courtyard sculpture  at C.I.A.  headquarters, misstated the decryption at the end of Passage Two. The decryption of those letters is “XLAYERTWO,” not “LEVELTWO.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague
title: Despite Evidence, Republicans Rallied Behind Trump. This Was Their Reasoning.
description: Several Senate Republicans said that even if President Trump did everything impeachment managers said, he should not be removed.
content: The Senate voted on Friday nearly along party lines to block additional witnesses and evidence in President Trump’s impeachment trial, effectively accelerating the proceedings toward a final vote, which is expected to be held Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: How to Take Equity Out of a Co-op
description: Like banks, co-ops set rules about how much shareholders can borrow. But there are ways to find the equity you seek in your home.
content: Q: I own a co-op in Brooklyn that’s worth about $450,000. I would like to take some equity out of the apartment for other uses, but my options seem limited. Reverse mortgages are not allowed in co-ops. I am a senior and worry that I would not qualify for a HELOC because of my age. And I do not want a mortgage. What are my options?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Garrard Conley
title: After Living as a Woman for Decades, He Staged His Own Gender Reveal
description: P. Carl’s memoir takes readers on the most personal journey there is.
content: BECOMING A MANThe Story of a TransitionBy P. Carl
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Hall
title: Asteroid That Killed the Dinosaurs Was Great for Bacteria
description: The smoldering crater left by the apocalyptic space rock became a nice home for blue-green algae within years of the impact.
content: The asteroid moved 24 times faster than a rifle bullet as it struck Earth some 66 million years ago. Its supersonic shock wave flattened trees across North and South America, and its heat wave sparked incomprehensibly large forest fires.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Caramelized! Shallot! Pasta!
description: Alison Roman’s new pasta, candied oranges, and more recipes.
content: The week’s most popular dishes include Alison Roman’s caramelized shallot pasta (above), Gabrielle Hamilton’s cold candied oranges and J. Kenji López-Alt’s moo shu mushrooms. Find more recipes in the collection below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman and Jim Tankersley
title: Independent Voters See Economy Improving, a Potential Boon to Trump
description: Consumer confidence has rebounded since recession warnings in the summer, particularly among voters who don’t lean toward either major party.
content: Americans are feeling better about the economy, a trend that, if it continues, could bolster President Trump’s prospects for re-election in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Klobuchar discusses 2002 case that put black teenager behind bars for life.
description: Civil rights activists and black community leaders in Minneapolis continue to call for her to suspend her campaign.
content: BETTENDORF — Senator Amy Klobuchar again called for any new evidence to be released in a 2002 murder case that was prosecuted while she was a county attorney, as civil rights activists and black community leaders in Minneapolis continued to call for her to suspend her campaign after a report raised questions about whether a black teenager was wrongly convicted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Democrats criticize D.N.C. change to debate rules.
description: Several candidates accused the Democratic National Committee of changing its qualification criteria to benefit Michael Bloomberg, who is not competing in the first four states.
content: DES MOINES — The Democratic National Committee released its latest debate qualification criteria on Friday, and as is tradition, some candidates think they’re unfair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Almukhtar, Thomas Kaplan and Rachel Shorey
title: 2020 Democrats Went on a Spending Spree in the Final Months of 2019
description: As the first nominating contests approached, Democratic presidential candidates spent millions on ads and staff in the fourth quarter of 2019.
content: As the first nominating contests approached, Democratic presidential candidates spent millions on ads and staff in the fourth quarter of 2019.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: Nigerians in New York Worry Expanded Travel Ban Will Hurt Family Ties
description: “It’s just not right to just blanket ban a group of people,” said one college professor who has lived in the U.S. for about 20 years.
content: The Trump administration’s expansion of the nation’s contentious travel ban on Friday to include Nigeria, Africa’s most populous nation, and several other countries deeply rattled immigrants, leaving some Nigerians in New York worried that it would break family ties and have a negative effect on both countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Once Skeptical, Senate Republicans Are All In on Trump
description: In pressing toward their preordained vote of acquittal, Senate Republicans made it clear they see their fortunes and futures intertwined with the president’s.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s control of Senate Republicans is nearly complete.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Buttigieg strategist says strong Iowa finish would give others ‘permission’ to back him.
description: The inference especially is that black voters, who currently demonstrate little support for the former mayor in polling, would follow the lead of Iowa caucusgoers and rally around him.
content: DES MOINES — Top strategists for Pete Buttigieg said they needed a top finish in Iowa on Monday and in New Hampshire the following week, but that first place was not a make-or-break deal for the campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck and Shane Goldmacher
title: Biden hires ‘Delegate Dave’ as campaign readies for ‘extended process,’ per memo.
description: In a private memo circulated to donors on Friday, the Biden campaign announced that it had hired Dave Huynh as the campaign’s delegate adviser.
content: NORTH LIBERTY — In a private memo circulated to donors on Friday, the Biden campaign announced that it had hired Dave Huynh as the campaign’s delegate adviser.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: A six-person newsroom is an Iowa must-follow.
description: If you’re on Twitter and paying attention to the presidential campaign, chances are you know of Iowa Starting Line.
content: DES MOINES — If you’re on Twitter and paying attention to the presidential campaign, chances are you know of Iowa Starting Line. It’s less than five years old, with six staff members, but its bare-bones operation now rivals The Des Moines Register in influence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Nigeria to Address Security Issues That Led to Visa Restrictions
description: Nigerians expressed disbelief and anger after the Trump administration announced the new policy.
content: LAGOS, Nigeria — Nigeria’s government pledged Saturday to try to address security issues the Trump administration cited in its decision to stop granting immigration visas to people from Africa’s most populous nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Biden to an undecided voter: ‘If I haven’t swayed you today, then I can’t sway you.’
description: An undecided voter told the former vice president that she hadn’t made up her mind, and asked what he would say to someone like her.
content: CEDAR RAPIDS — As Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. neared the end of the rope line at his afternoon event here, shaking hands and taking pictures, he encountered Jaimee Warbasse, a hairstylist from Cedar Rapids who was still undecided.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Andrew Yang raised $6.7 million in January.
description: He was the first candidate to reveal his fund-raising haul for the month.
content: DES MOINES — Andrew Yang, the former tech entrepreneur, raised more than $6.7 million in January, his campaign said on Saturday, becoming the first candidate to reveal his fund-raising haul for the month. Of that amount, he raised $1.2 million on Jan. 31.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Buttigieg warns against repeat of 2016 fights.
description: The former mayor distilled his campaign message to a plea to Democrats.
content: WATERLOO — On the penultimate day of his Iowa caucus campaign, former Mayor Pete Buttigieg of South Bend, Ind., distilled his campaign message to a plea to Democrats: Let’s get over the fights that divided the party in 2016.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alissa J. Rubin
title: Iraq Names New Prime Minister Who Praises ‘Bravery’ of Protesters
description: Anti-government demonstrations have been raging since October, demanding an end to political corruption.
content: BAGHDAD — Iraq’s president stepped in to appoint a new prime minister after the Parliament failed to do so for two months, leaving the country largely rudderless at a time of multiple political crises.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Goldstein
title: Coronavirus: New York City Eyes First Suspected Case, Officials Say
description: A sample was being sent to the federal authorities for confirmation, the city Health Department said.
content: New York City health officials announced on Saturday that a patient at Bellevue Hospital Center might have the new coronavirus and that samples were being sent to the federal authorities for laboratory testing. If confirmed, it would be the first known instance of the virus in New York City.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Fausset, Manny Fernandez and Sabrina Tavernise
title: Three Ex-Presidents Faced Impeachment. We Visited Their Historic Sites.
description: We visited the presidential museums, libraries and sites dedicated to Andrew Johnson, Richard Nixon and Bill Clinton to talk to visitors about the impeachment facing President Trump.
content: The first president to be impeached stood in the way of Reconstruction, fired a Cabinet member without the then-required Senate approval and brought “disgrace, ridicule, hatred, contempt and reproach” on Congress. The second who faced impeachment covered up the wiretapping and break-in at the opposing party’s headquarters. The third disgraced president had an affair with a White House intern, and then lied about it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: ‘It Would Have Been Nicer if Bernie Was Here’
description: Inside the very weird homestretch in Iowa, where candidates were thin on the ground, but reporters were not.
content: OTTUMWA, Iowa — As excellent as the Bernie Sanders event was — as excellent as it was to hear from the filmmaker Michael Moore and to eat Ben & Jerry’s ice cream scooped by the actual Ben and the actual Jerry, longtime Sanders supporters — it would have been even more excellent, was the general feeling, if Mr. Sanders himself had been able to come to Ottumwa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis
title: Greece’s Answer to Migrants, a Floating Barrier, Is Called a ‘Disgrace’
description: Rights groups have condemned the plan, warning that it would increase the dangers faced by asylum seekers.
content: ATHENS — As Greece struggles to deal with a seemingly endless influx of migrants from neighboring Turkey, the conservative government has a contentious new plan to respond to the problem: a floating net barrier to avert smuggling boats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Former Coast Guard Lieutenant Is Sentenced to 13 Years in Prison on Gun and Drug Charges
description: Christopher Paul Hasson plotted to kill journalists, Democratic politicians, professors, Supreme Court justices and those he described as “leftists in general,” federal prosecutors have said.
content: A former Coast Guard lieutenant who described himself as a white nationalist was sentenced Friday to more than 13 years in prison after pleading guilty last year to federal gun and drug charges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley and Steven Lee Myers
title: As New Coronavirus Spread, China’s Old Habits Delayed Fight
description: At critical turning points, Chinese authorities put secrecy and order ahead of openly confronting the growing crisis and risking public alarm or political embarrassment.
content: WUHAN, China — A mysterious illness had stricken seven patients at a hospital, and a doctor tried to warn his medical school classmates. “Quarantined in the emergency department,” the doctor, Li Wenliang, wrote in an online chat group on Dec. 30, referring to patients.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Seymour
title: Brexit Has Arrived. But Boris Johnson’s Reign Is Just Beginning.
description: With his signature campaign promise fulfilled, the prime minister can now reshape Britain for a generation.
content: LONDON — The moment has arrived. Britain is out of the European Union. Prime Minister Boris Johnson and his “People’s Government” — it scarcely calls itself Conservative at this point — has fulfilled the promise on which it was elected in December and “got Brexit done.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Roberts says it would be ‘inappropriate’ for him to act as a tie-breaker.
description: “I think it would be inappropriate for me, an unelected official from a different branch of government, to change that result so that the motion would succeed,” he said.
content: Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, the Democratic leader, on Friday evening asked a pointed question of Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr.: Was he aware that the chief justice during President Andrew Johnson’s impeachment trial acted as the tie-breaker on two separate votes?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alicia Parlapiano
title: A consequential vote is captured in pencil.
description: Senator Lisa Murkowski, Republican of Alaska, said on Friday that she would not support the motion.
content: The motion to include new witnesses and documents in the trial became less and less likely this week as prospective Republican defectors announced that they would not join Democrats in voting “yes.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Trump signed off on the plan for his trial’s close.
description: The Senate majority leader is said to have shared the details of the resolution with the president, who gave his approval.
content: Before he introduced a resolution laying out the final days of the impeachment trial, Senator Mitch McConnell placed a call to President Trump to run it by him, according to a person with knowledge of the call.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Democrats unsuccessfully try to force four amendments.
description: All four failed.
content: As senators prepared to set the procedures for the final moments of the impeachment trial, Democrats tried to force four amendments to the resolution that would allow for the subpoenaing of documents and witnesses.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: With the Exit Finally Official, Many Britons Feel the Need for a Period of Recovery
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, February 1, 2020.
content: “The irony is that Brexit was all about taking back control, but we’ve never been so out of control. No one even knows what the reality of Brexit will look like.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: Trying to Find the Signal in the Noise of Hall of Fame Voting
description: A relatively new statistic aims to quantify the likelihood of election to the Pro Football Hall of Fame. Alan Faneca should be excited, while Isaac Bruce’s wait may continue.
content: Isaac Bruce was a central cog in the St. Louis Rams’ “Greatest Show on Turf” offense. For 16 seasons, Bruce was a consistent vertical threat at wide receiver, and he ranks in the N.F.L.’s top 15 for career receptions (13th), receiving yards (fifth) and touchdown catches (12th). He was the leading receiver in a Super Bowl victory, and his No. 80 jersey was retired by the Rams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: A Wedding Day That Left Them Shook
description: Hours after the morning wedding of Lauren Schneider and Lawrence Moss, the couple found themselves on very shaky ground as a 7.7 magnitude earthquake hit Jamaica.
content: Just hours after Lauren Schneider and Lawrence Moss were married on Jan. 28 at Sandals South Coast, a resort in Whitehouse, Jamaica, they received phone calls from many friends and family who couldn’t attend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Waldman
title: Probing the Murder of a Pakistani Internet Sensation
description: “A Woman Like Her,” by Sanam Maher, investigates the killing of a 26-year-old social-media celebrity by her brother, and a culture in which independent, outspoken women are not easily tolerated.
content: A WOMAN LIKE HER The Story Behind the Honor Killing of a Social Media Star By Sanam Maher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Ortved
title: When Dressing for Work is Part of the Job
description: At Moda Operandi, the luxury runway website, cargo pants won’t do, unless they’re fashion approved.
content: Barneys New York and Opening Ceremony may be closing, but fashion e-tailers are doing just fine. Last fall, Moda Operandi, the luxury site where customers can order clothes directly off the runways of fashion week, opened a 30,000-square-foot office in Industry City in Brooklyn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eleanor Stanford
title: The Best Movies and TV Shows Coming to Netflix, Amazon and More in February
description: Every month, subscription streaming services add a new batch of titles to their libraries. Here are our picks for February.
content: For more recommendations on what to stream, sign up for our twice-weekly Watching newsletter here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: Katie Sowers Seized Her Chances, and Now She’s Coaching in the Super Bowl
description: Sowers needed an assist to get her foot in the door. Then she burst through to become the first woman to coach in the N.F.L.’s championship game.
content: MIAMI — Katie Sowers did not come to the Super Bowl to be a token for the N.F.L., for the San Francisco 49ers, or for the news media. She came to coach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor and Matt Stevens
title: Iowa, Iowa, Iowa: This Week in the 2020 Race
description: It’s all Iowa, all the time. You may not have been there, but we were. Here’s a rundown of what happened.
content: DES MOINES — Two days to go, people! Two days until the day we’ve been anticipating for more than a year. We’re in the homestretch. It’s almost ov —
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anita Gates
title: Monique Van Vooren, Actress With a Diverse Résumé, Dies at 92
description: Her filmography ranged from “Tarzan and the She-Devil” to “Wall Street.” She also appeared on “Batman” and on game shows and sang in cabarets.
content: Monique Van Vooren, the Belgian-born actress and singer whose highly eclectic résumé included roles in “Tarzan and the She-Devil,” “Andy Warhol’s Frankenstein,” the Pop Art television series “Batman” and “Wall Street,” died on Jan. 25 at her home in Manhattan. She was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Plans for Alabama’s Deadly Prisons ‘Won’t Fix the Horrors’
description: A panel appointed by the governor acknowledged that its recommendations could not fully address what the Justice Department has called “severe, systemic” conditions.
content: WASHINGTON — After months of promising to fix Alabama’s dangerously violent prison system, a panel appointed by the governor issued recommendations this week that would do little to address the underlying problems identified last year in a scathing Justice Department report, which documented prisoners being routinely assaulted and tortured, sometimes with the knowledge and even participation of prison guards.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Hillary Clinton Slams Bernie Sanders for Not Working to Unite Democrats in 2016
description: In a podcast interview on Friday, Mrs. Clinton also described the caucuses in Iowa, where Mr. Sanders leads in some polls, as “undemocratic.”
content: DES MOINES — Hillary Clinton said on Friday in a podcast interview that Senator Bernie Sanders and his supporters did not do enough to unify the Democratic Party after the prolonged 2016 primary, calling the behavior of his supporters “distressing” and saying it affected the general election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: The youth climate group Zero Hour endorses Bernie Sanders.
description: Polls show that climate change is a crucial issue for Democratic voters, especially young ones.
content: DES MOINES — Zero Hour, the youth-led coalition that organized huge global climate marches in 2018, endorsed Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont on Saturday morning, citing “his radical and motivating plan to address the climate crisis and his support for the Green New Deal.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: With the Exit Finally Official, Many Britons Feel the Need for a Period of Recovery
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, February 1, 2020.
content: “The irony is that Brexit was all about taking back control, but we’ve never been so out of control. No one even knows what the reality of Brexit will look like.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Trump signed off on the plan for his trial’s close.
description: The Senate majority leader is said to have shared the details of the resolution with the president, who gave his approval.
content: Before he introduced a resolution laying out the final days of the impeachment trial, Senator Mitch McConnell placed a call to President Trump to run it by him, according to a person with knowledge of the call.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Roberts says it would be ‘inappropriate’ for him to act as a tie-breaker.
description: “I think it would be inappropriate for me, an unelected official from a different branch of government, to change that result so that the motion would succeed,” he said.
content: Senator Chuck Schumer of New York, the Democratic leader, on Friday evening asked a pointed question of Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr.: Was he aware that the chief justice during President Andrew Johnson’s impeachment trial acted as the tie-breaker on two separate votes?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alicia Parlapiano
title: A consequential vote is captured in pencil.
description: Senator Lisa Murkowski, Republican of Alaska, said on Friday that she would not support the motion.
content: The motion to include new witnesses and documents in the trial became less and less likely this week as prospective Republican defectors announced that they would not join Democrats in voting “yes.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Democrats unsuccessfully try to force four amendments.
description: All four failed.
content: As senators prepared to set the procedures for the final moments of the impeachment trial, Democrats tried to force four amendments to the resolution that would allow for the subpoenaing of documents and witnesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember
title: Sanders makes his electability case.
description: In the final weekend before the Iowa caucuses, Bernie Sanders made his most forceful case yet that he was the most electable candidate.
content: INDIANOLA — On the final weekend before the Iowa caucuses, Bernie Sanders made his most forceful case yet that he was the most electable candidate, saying that he would defeat President Trump in the general election because he could excite voters, speak to the working class and expose Mr. Trump’s populist “hypocrisy.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: A front-row seat at Elizabeth Warren’s rally.
description: A captivated girl at Elizabeth Warren’s rally in Cedar Rapids.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: John Kerry, poet.
description: He closed with a rhyme of sorts about Joe Biden’s ability to defeat President Trump.
content: NORTH LIBERTY — John Kerry, the former secretary of state and presidential nominee, had just ticked through Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s record and his character as he urged Iowans to caucus for his longtime Senate colleague. Then he closed with a rhyme of sorts about Mr. Biden’s ability to defeat President Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Klobuchar claims path to the White House is through the Midwest.
description: Senator Amy Klobuchar summed up her final pitch with a geographic appeal.
content: BETTENDORF — In her first event back in Iowa after spending most of the week tethered to Washington for the impeachment trial, Senator Amy Klobuchar summed up her final pitch with a geographic appeal: the path to a Democratic victory in 2020 is through the Midwest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher and Katie Glueck
title: Joe Biden just revealed about how much he raised in January.
description: The Biden campaign sent its top donors a private memo on Friday touting that January had been the campaign’s “strongest month of fund-raising since launch.”
content: DES MOINES — The Biden campaign sent its top donors a private memo on Friday touting that January had been the campaign’s “strongest month of fund-raising since launch.” There were no numbers revealed in the memo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Pete Buttigieg tries out being human.
description: An Iowa Democrat asked him to look inside himself and reveal “a moment that you felt vulnerable.”
content: CLINTON — Every so often, Pete Buttigieg gets an out-of-left field question from an Iowa Democrat that’s not about how he’d beat President Trump or what he’d do to improve people’s health care.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Trump, Unrepentant and Unleashed
description: The diabolical duo of Donald and Mitch, serving their own interests, not the national one.
content: WASHINGTON — During a meeting with Donald Trump at Trump Tower in June of 2016, with the opéra bouffe builder improbably heading toward the nomination despite a skeletal campaign crew on a floor below, I asked when he would pivot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helen T. Verongos
title: Mary Higgins Clark, Best-Selling Queen of Suspense, Dies at 92
description: She became a world-renowned author writing about “nice people whose lives are invaded.”
content: Mary Higgins Clark, a fixture on best-seller lists for decades whose more than 50 novels earned her the sobriquet Queen of Suspense, died on Friday in Naples, Fla. She was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: While Stained in History, Trump Will Emerge From Trial Triumphant and Unshackled
description: His acquittal in the Senate assured, the emboldened president will take his victory and grievance to the campaign trail, no longer worried about congressional constraint.
content: WASHINGTON — Ralph Waldo Emerson seemed to foresee the lesson of the Senate impeachment trial of President Trump. “When you strike at a king,” Emerson famously said, “you must kill him.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Trump, Unrepentant and Unleashed
description: The diabolical duo of Donald and Mitch, serving their own interests, not the national one.
content: WASHINGTON — During a meeting with Donald Trump at Trump Tower in June of 2016, with the opéra bouffe builder improbably heading toward the nomination despite a skeletal campaign crew on a floor below, I asked when he would pivot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Helen T. Verongos
title: Mary Higgins Clark, Best-Selling Queen of Suspense, Dies at 92
description: She became a world-renowned author writing about “nice people whose lives are invaded.”
content: Mary Higgins Clark, a fixture on best-seller lists for decades whose more than 50 novels earned her the sobriquet Queen of Suspense, died on Friday in Naples, Fla. She was 92.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Eavis
title: WeWork Names Veteran Real Estate Executive as New Chief
description: Sandeep Mathrani will take over the operator of shared office space, which was on the brink of financial collapse last year.
content: WeWork, the troubled operator of shared office space, has named Sandeep Mathrani, a senior executive at the commercial real estate company Brookfield Properties, as its new chief executive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard A. Oppel Jr
title: A Cancer Patient Stole Groceries Worth $109.63. She Was Sentenced to 10 Months.
description: The lieutenant governor of Pennsylvania, John Fetterman, said the punishment was overly harsh and offered to personally repay the grocery store.
content: As lieutenant governor of Pennsylvania, John Fetterman is a very busy man. But he was prepared to drop everything on Friday and drive to a Weis Markets in Lebanon, Pa., to hand deliver a personal check for $109.63, the exact sum of groceries that a woman with advanced cancer was recently convicted of stealing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Brexit Is Here! Sort Of
description: Britain has formally left the European Union, but difficult trade talks remain before the two are severed.
content: Finally, after 1,317 days of confusion, rancor and endless votes in Parliament, it was time for Brexit. On Wednesday, teary members of the European Parliament joined hands and sang “Auld Lang Syne,” a clock projected onto 10 Downing Street counted down the minutes, Union Jacks lined the Mall before Buckingham Palace.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Biden says his focus is on defeating Trump at the ballot box.
description: “I’m focusing on how I beat Donald Trump, how I get the nomination and beat him,” he said.
content: As he walked into a presidential campaign event in Mount Pleasant, Iowa, Joseph R. Biden Jr. lamented the vote to block new witnesses in President Trump’s impeachment trial, but said he wanted to focus on defeating him at the ballot box.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Witnesses
description: Republicans voted almost unanimously against hearing new evidence in the impeachment trial, some saying they wanted to leave President Trump’s political future in the hands of the electorate.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device: Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: A Former F.B.I. Negotiator and His Tips for Travel
description: Chris Voss details how empathy, bargaining and other tactics can be applied to landing travel perks, avoiding travel penalties and more.
content: When Chris Voss showed up at his hotel in Los Angeles recently before the official check-in time, the clerk informed him there would be an early check-in fee. Minutes later, he left the reception desk with the fee waived and a key to an upgraded room.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Concepción de León
title: For Her Debut, Abi Daré Confronts ‘Dreams and Intelligence That We Kill’
description: Writing “The Girl With the Louding Voice,” about a 14-year-old employed as a housemaid, challenged how the novelist viewed a common practice in her native Nigeria.
content: The inspiration for Abi Daré’s first book struck when one of her daughters, then 8, didn’t feel like unloading the dishwasher.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Gendler
title: Australian Open: Matches to Watch on Saturday Night (Into Sunday)
description: Dominic Thiem looks to unseat Novak Djokovic, and two Australian wild cards look to cap a Cinderella story.
content: Novak Djokovic, the defending champion, is the most decorated singles player in the history of the Australian Open. With seven titles in Melbourne, beginning in 2008, Djokovic is at home on the hardcourts Down Under. The world No. 2, he has galloped toward his eighth Australian Open title, and looks in excellent form. He skated past Roger Federer in the semifinal, winning in straight sets, on his quest to match Federer’s record of 20 Grand Slam titles.
source.name: The New York Times

title: When Did the Super Bowl Halftime Show Become Political?
description: A conversation about how its meaning has evolved over the last two decades.
content: For many years — decades even — the Super Bowl halftime show was an uncontroversial distraction, a way for the N.F.L. to retain eyeballs and collect advertising dollars in between the two halves of the most watched game of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Every other Sunday, we complete a full orbit around Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon.
content: ACROSTIC — Today’s excerpt is by Rachel Carson, the 20th-century nature writer whose brilliant “Silent Spring” greatly contributed to the modern environmental movement. Her work also foreshadowed many of the predicaments we find ourselves in today on our beautiful and fragile planet. The passage is from a different work, “(The) Sense of Wonder,” which was originally a 1950s magazine article presented as a way for adults to foster a sensitivity to nature in children.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Western Iowa is blanketed in snow.
description: Wide open spaces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz and Jacey Fortin
title: Student Suspended Over Dreadlocks Is Invited to the Oscars by ‘Hair Love’ Team
description: DeAndre Arnold was told his dreadlocks violated his Texas high school’s dress code. Now he has been invited to the Oscars by the celebrity couple Gabrielle Union and Dwyane Wade.
content: A black student in Texas who was suspended because his high school said the way he wore his dreadlocks violated its dress code has been invited to the Oscars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Joe Biden gets back on track.
description: Mr. Biden, who had been delivering an animated version of his stump speech, was briefly knocked off course when someone needed medical attention.
content: CEDAR RAPIDS — Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., who had been delivering an animated version of his stump speech, was briefly knocked off course when someone needed medical attention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: Jay-Z Takes on the Super Bowl
description: Why are Roc Nation and the N.F.L. doing business this Super Bowl weekend? Well, social justice is expensive.
content: A few years ago, the National Football League approached Jay-Z about performing at the Super Bowl halftime show. To perform “Run This Town,” he was asked if he would bring Rihanna and Kanye West, who appear on the track, along with him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: The expectations game roars back to life.
description: On Saturday morning, in the final push before the caucuses, Mr. Biden’s campaign had a fresh set of talking points.
content: NORTH LIBERTY — Last fall, Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s campaign aides insisted that he didn’t need to win the leadoff caucus state. Amid a major winter press here, Mr. Biden told reporters, “I’m running to win.” And on Saturday morning, in the final push before the caucuses, Mr. Biden’s campaign aimed to set a fresh set of expectations: He’ll be “competitive,” and he’s not going anywhere, whatever happens in Iowa.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Standing on their seats to see Mayor Pete.
description: People stood on chairs to catch a glimpse of Pete Buttigieg during his rally in Waterloo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: The Only Way to Remove Trump
description: To eject the president, you need to beat him.
content: All you have to do is beat him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: Mayor Pete’s Gay Reckoning
description: Win or lose in Iowa, Buttigieg has challenged and changed America.
content: ANKENY, Iowa — You can listen to long stretches of Pete Buttigieg’s remarks and hear little or no reference to the trailblazing nature of his campaign. You can almost forget.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: What if Brexit Works?
description: Britain is remaking itself again. The shape of its society and economy, and its place in the world, are very much up for grabs.
content: LONDON — Britain’s departure from the European Union on Friday drew a mournful reaction from many people who have long viewed Brexit as consigning their country, once the vanguard of Europe, to a future of economic mediocrity and geopolitical irrelevance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: Kobe and Gianna Bryant’s Bond Was Made of Love and Basketball
description: The former N.B.A. guard Jason Terry last saw Kobe coaching Gianna’s Mamba Academy team a week ago. Terry and his girls’ team were supposed to face them the day of the helicopter crash.
content: Playing against Kobe Bryant for 17 years convinced Jason Terry of one thing: He needed to prepare zealously before coaching against him for the first time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karan Deep Singh
title: Modi’s Budget Offers Few Solutions to Revive India’s Weak Economy
description: As the slowing economy threatens Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s grip on power, the government unveiled a modest budget that one economist called “smoke and mirrors.”
content: NEW DELHI — India is stuck in its biggest economic slump in more than a decade, but Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s budget for the new year, unveiled on Saturday, offers only small steps to try to create a turnaround.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: The Lakers Remember Kobe Bryant With a Game ‘Straight From the Heart’
description: The Lakers returned to the court for the first time since the death of Kobe Bryant and eight others in a helicopter crash, playing a game that was more reflection than sport.
content: LOS ANGELES — Nothing about the game was normal. Not the tributes. Not the chants. Not the emotion. Not the reflection.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Trump Threw Weighty Refugee Decisions to Local Government, With Painful Results
description: President Trump’s executive order granting local officials veto power over refugee resettlement has divided communities and left immigrants feeling unwanted.
content: EAST LONGMEADOW, Mass. — In a gray-walled, institutional hall usually reserved for prosaic debates over traffic and town budgets, Mohamoud Abdirahman rose from the audience last month and approached a panel of five town councilmen sitting in judgment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson
title: China Increasingly Walled Off as Countries Seek to Stem Coronavirus
description: The number of deaths from the virus outbreak rose to 304 and the number of cases soared to more than 14,000 as Australia and Japan joined the United States in imposing travel restrictions.
content: HONG KONG — New walls are rising between China and the world as the country grapples with a fast-moving coronavirus and its mounting death toll.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: U.S. Tweets Support for Iranian Chess Official but Ban Wouldn’t Let Her In
description: American embassies appeared to sympathize with an Iranian woman who feared returning to Iran after an image of her looking like she was not wearing a hijab circulated online.
content: The Iranian chess official said she began seeing the messages of support from American government officials soon after she said she was afraid of returning to her country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: Indonesia Deports U.S. Journalist Jailed Over Visa Issue
description: Philip Jacobson, who works for the environmental news organization Mongabay, was put on a plane to New York.
content: BANGKOK — An American journalist who was jailed in Indonesia for allegedly violating the terms of his visa has been deported and was expected to arrive in New York on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Klobuchar urges Iowans to look past the caucuses.
description: “I’ve got the endorsement of every single major newspaper in New Hampshire that has put out an endorsement,” she said.
content: BETTENDORF — An overflow crowd in a bike shop greeted Senator Amy Klobuchar Saturday morning on the first day of her jetsetting trip around Iowa, powered by a chartered plane to get to the four corners of the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz and Jacey Fortin
title: Student Suspended Over Dreadlocks Is Invited to the Oscars by ‘Hair Love’ Team
description: DeAndre Arnold was told his dreadlocks violated his Texas high school’s dress code. Now he has been invited to the Oscars by the celebrity couple Gabrielle Union and Dwyane Wade.
content: A black student in Texas who was suspended because his high school said the way he wore his dreadlocks violated its dress code has been invited to the Oscars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronen Bergman, Anton Troianovski and Kenneth P. Vogel
title: Giuliani Sought Help for Client in Meeting With Ukrainian Official
description: As he discussed the possibility of a White House meeting for Ukraine’s president, President Trump’s lawyer asked to save the Kyiv mayor’s job.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — When Rudolph W. Giuliani met with a top aide to Ukraine’s president last summer, he discussed the prospect of a coveted White House meeting for the president while seeking Ukraine’s commitment to certain investigations that could benefit President Trump politically.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: The Yang Gang hasn’t settled on a second choice.
description: Mr. Yang may have difficulty reaching the 15 percent threshold required to earn delegates in many caucuses.
content: BOONE — A couple of hundred people packed a Mexican restaurant for Andrew Yang, who was running late.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Joe Biden gets back on track.
description: Mr. Biden, who had been delivering an animated version of his stump speech, was briefly knocked off course when someone needed medical attention.
content: CEDAR RAPIDS — Former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr., who had been delivering an animated version of his stump speech, was briefly knocked off course when someone needed medical attention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Rosman
title: Jay-Z Takes on the Super Bowl
description: Why are Roc Nation and the N.F.L. doing business this Super Bowl weekend? Well, social justice is expensive.
content: A few years ago, the National Football League approached Jay-Z about performing at the Super Bowl halftime show. To perform “Run This Town,” he was asked if he would bring Rihanna and Kanye West, who appear on the track, along with him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Kaplan
title: A new picture of the Democratic money race.
description: The two billionaires in the Democratic primary race are spending enormous amounts of money on their candidacies, according to new filings with the Federal Election Commission.
content: DES MOINES — Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont remains a financial powerhouse, and the two billionaires in the Democratic primary race are spending enormous amounts of money on their candidacies, according to new filings with the Federal Election Commission.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Heckler interrupts Biden: ‘Don’t settle for Joe.’
description: In response, Mr. Biden suggested that the protester was one of the dozens of pro-Trump Republican surrogates who had deployed to Iowa this weekend.
content: NORTH LIBERTY — A heckler interrupted former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. at his event here, comparing him to Hillary Clinton and urging the crowd, “don’t settle for Joe.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Tommasini
title: Peter Serkin, 72, Dies; Pianist With Pedigree Who Forged a New Path
description: Descended from two eminent musical families, he became a maverick, questioned the establishment and fostered a career on his own terms.
content: Peter Serkin, a pianist admired for his insightful interpretations, technically pristine performances and tenacious commitment to contemporary music, died on Saturday morning at his home in Red Hook, N.Y., in Dutchess County, near the campus of Bard University, where he was on the faculty. He was 72.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: Pete Buttigieg answers French reporter’s question, in French.
description: The former mayor answered a question from a French television journalist about how he planned to win.
content: OELWEIN — The quadrennial invasion of Iowa by out-of-state college students, busloads of tour groups and the foreign press is in full effect and Pete Buttigieg is happy to oblige.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Audubon Society
description: Brian Herrick and Christopher Adams take us on a flight of fancy.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — You know those puzzles where your first guess is never right, not once?  Where the constructor sneaks in alternate meanings, twists of phrase, surprising variant definitions, dry punnery?  Those puzzles are cats, predators that cruelly toy with their prey (and decimate songbirds, by the way, which is why you need to dress every cat you encounter in a Elizabethan ruff, be it inside or outdoors).  Today’s puzzle is not a cat; today’s puzzle is a herding dog, here to provide you with amusement and wisdom without making your brain nervous that it can’t keep up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karan Deep Singh
title: Modi’s Budget Offers Few Solutions to Revive India’s Weak Economy
description: As the slowing economy threatens Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s grip on power, the government unveiled a modest budget that one economist called “smoke and mirrors.”
content: NEW DELHI — India is stuck in its biggest economic slump in more than a decade, but Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s budget for the new year, unveiled on Saturday, offers only small steps to try to create a turnaround.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: U.S. Tweets Support for Iranian Chess Official but Ban Wouldn’t Let Her In
description: American embassies appeared to sympathize with an Iranian woman who feared returning to Iran after an image of her looking like she was not wearing a hijab circulated online.
content: The Iranian chess official said she began seeing the messages of support from American government officials soon after she said she was afraid of returning to her country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock
title: Indonesia Deports U.S. Journalist Jailed Over Visa Issue
description: Philip Jacobson, who works for the environmental news organization Mongabay, was put on a plane to New York.
content: BANGKOK — An American journalist who was jailed in Indonesia for allegedly violating the terms of his visa has been deported and was expected to arrive in New York on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times
